page.title: 10FARMING DARTMOOR
page.content: Most farmers rear sheep and beef cattle.They grow kale and some turnips to feed their stock in the long, cold winter.Sheep graze on kale during the day and are put into pasture fields at night.Most enclosed land is pasture . Beef provides the main profit in some cases.Calves are kept for two years and then sent to market and the money is used to restock.Sheep are mainly White-faced Dartmoors,Welsh Blacks or Pedigree Lleyns.They are sheared in June-July.The fleeces are sold at Buckfastleigh for Â£3-Â£4 each.The farmers remember the bad winter of 1962-3.It lashed with rain all Christmas Day and it started snowing in the evening.The snow reached the hedge-tops and lasted until March.This year,April snow covered the sheep and lambs' grazing ground and hay was in short supply.
